What lack of liquidity are you seeing in Ethereum? It has 1/3 the liquidity of BTC, and only 1/6th the market cap (it actually has a higher ratio of liquidity to market cap) And it achieved this in just 3.5 years.
FIO is one of the most important projects in crypto in terms of real usability for all blockchains (bitcoin, ethereum, etc), especially with their privacy-by-design philosophy.

I think you might be unwisely dismissing the element of time. Bitcoin's massive lead is due to many virtues of it as a specific project, but one important element is that it is 10 years old. Ethereum is 3.5 yrs old, and during its life has grown much faster in both price and use.

3/ I’m not knowledgeable enough to have an informed opinion on this topic, but worth noting that competing clients (in both ethereum and bitcoin) have fairly frequently accidentally HF’ed, but multiple minority clients is critical to political decentralization imo.

2/ addressing this. Are there any ethereum initiatives to actively discourage usage of the most popular client? Is this an explicit goal? Bitcoin devs disagree with each other on this point, but majority seem to favor a single dominant client to avoid accidental HFS.

It’s been a long running distracting troll. Blockstream has never produced a protocol change in bitcoin, ever. Nor has anyone else other than satoshi. We can debate the extent to which a dominant client is the asset or protocol, but I’m not aware of any ethereum plans directly

I keep it simple for normies. Bitcoin is always the gateway. Ethereum is optimised for smart contracts while Bitcoin is optimised for store of value. That does not make it more advanced, just more vulnerable. SoV in Ethereum is a secondary halo effect.

Lol. Now you’re arguing on my side. Bitcoin was first generation growth of a forest, Ethereum is second stage after the undergrowth was put in. Second stage growth should be much faster. Being young is no excuse for lack of liquidity.

So is Tether, EOS, Bitcoin Cash, Neo and Ethereum is also very young. My point being all coins ride on Bitcoin’s Halo Effect, so being young is no excuse. It’s a different time in the industry than 2012.

I've been vocal about the Ethereum community's need to provide credible time-consistency around $ETH supply, and am seeing good traction to that end: https://docs.ethhub.io/ethereum-basics/monetary-policy/
Put another way, #Ethereum’s utility as a ledger to anchor value into keeps going up, while $ETH is mostly flat
